text: Most integral membrane proteins, regardless of their route to the membrane (SRP dependent or independent) or their mechanism of insertion (co-translational vs post-translational) use the translocon to bury their hydrophobic segments into the lipid bilayer. The role of the translocon goes far beyond the partition process itself; it discriminates between what will or will not be a TM segment, sets the topology of the protein (based on the topology determinants present in the polypeptide sequence) and facilitates coordinated insertion of multiple TM segments.
